page.title: 03Farming - Treveague
page.content: The whetter family have lived at Treveague since 1942.The farmhouse was built in the 1500's,but there was a farm here long before that.Treveague itself is 160 acres;the farmer rents a further 65 acres from the National Trust.The land is cultivated grassland for hay and silage,with some rough grazing on the cliffs.It grows 40 acres of corn each year,also rape and stubble turnips for strip grazing.The land produces enough to feed all its animals,chiefly Friesians for beef and one house cow for milk.Treveague also has a registered campsite for 30 tents or caravans overlooking the sea.The visitors enjoy the many pets at Treveague - goats,guinea-pigs,rabbits, ponies,canaries and finches.
